farbgeist wrote:
> Hi there,
> 
> is there a web-scale frontier implementation for Heretrix? 
> As I understand any Heretrix instance will run out of memory as the memory consumption of the frontier expands.
> Right?

Not true; the crawl should continue without problems as long as you've 
still got free disk space on whatever volume holds your crawl's 'state' 
directory. Frontier operations -- testing URIs for prior inclusion, and 
enqueuing new URIs -- will become slower as they require seeks/reads 
over ever-larger disk structures.

(Some of the summary reports designed for smaller crawls -- notably the 
'seeds report', maybe others -- may try to use an unbounded amount of 
RAM when triggered in Heritrix 1.x and 2.x. The workaround is not to 
trigger them -- but also all known issues of this type have been fixed 
as of the latest prerelease Heritrix 3-beta builds.)

For crawls where a single machine is expected to visit > 100 million 
URIs, to avoid the slowdown as the crawl grows, we usually swap the 
disk-based already-included class (BdbUriUniqFilter) for an in-memory
implementation (BloomUriUniqFilter) that doesn't slow over time, but 
instead has a small false-positive rate (that then grows if the filter 
becomes oversaturated). (The defaults, which are adjustable if you have 
more RAM, use 512MB to acheive a 1-in-4-million false-positive rate up 
through 125 million discovered URIs.)

IA has done crawls up to 2 billion URIs with Heritrix using multiple 
machines, and we know of outside teams who have done crawls of over 8 
billion URIs using the same general techniques, which can be scaled 
further with more machines.

Separate but related: we've long been interested in having a 
already-included structure matching that described in the Mercator 
papers (or as updated in the recent IRLbot paper), which would offer a 
disk-based structure that wouldn't slow as much with growth as our 
current implementation. Our active crawls haven't yet reached the scale 
where such an implementation is urgent. (The manner in which candidate 
URIs are passed through a duplicate filter, allowing for batching and 
without the assumption of instant enqueuing, was designed to allow these 
techniques to be dropped-in when needed.)
